div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1904.

div.head: THE POLYTECHNIC SCHOOL.
div.p: We publish to-day a very important notice issued by the Ministry of Public Works, which will, without doubt, cause very general satisfaction in Egypt. It had long been recognised both in and out of the Ministry that the growing unpopularity among Egyptians of the Polytechnic School's course was likely, should it continue, to cause a dangerous shortage in the number of engineers qualified for Government service in a country where Irrigation is all in all. We need not repeat the causes of the diminution of the numbers of candidates, the tale has been told many times in our columns, and Sunday's note merely sums up what we may call the professional reasons. Outside these there was the well-known fact, which is perhaps left unmentioned as lying outside the scope of the Ministry of Public Works, that the cost of living in Egypt has increased so rapidly in the last few years that what was quite recently a fair salary has now become ludicrously inadequate. Another effect of the above causes deserves notice. The underpayment, probably inevitable and regrettable in any case, of the native gineers employed in Government service, aided to bring about the overcrowding of the legal profession from which Egypt now suffers.

The financial difficulties which so hampered Egypt are at last removed, and this improvement of the conditions of service under the Ministry of Public Works is one of the first fruits of their removal. It will bring in more recruits, and good recruits, to the Irrigation Service, it will lessen the temptations to which underpaid officials are particularly exposed, and it will in some degree reduce the con gestion of the legal and medical professions. On the other hand, we are very glad to note that not only will virtue be rewarded but vice, too, will be punished in the most approved fashion, for officials who have become "suspect" -and we fancy that the Irrigation Depart ment can generally form a pretty good idea of what are or are not just grounds for suspecting an engineer of corrupt practices-are not to participate in the reward bestowed on hard and honest service alone. If we have any criticism to make, it is this-that the Department should have admitted that a low rate of pay was an "extenuating circumstance" in cases of the kind. We agree that it is, but in a country where the giving and taking of "backsheesh" by petty officials is not yet generally regarded as a vile and dishonourable thing, this admission is sure to be made use of in the future by a variety of persons with grievances among a people where the "man in the street" merely apologises for performances which the public morality of other nations visits with the severest condemnation. But it is ungracious to look a gift horse in the mouth, and we have ample cause to congratulate the Government and the Ministry on the steps that have been taken to improve the lot of the native civil servant and to raise to a still higher level the efficiency of a remarkably successful service.

div.head:
THE BALTIC FLEET.
SAILS FOR ATLANTIC.
NEW VERSION OF OUTRAGE.
THE INTERNATIONAL COMMISSION.
BOARD OF TRADE ENQUIRY,

div.p: The remainder of the Baltic Fleet has left the port. They steamed in the direction of the Atlantic.
The Baltic fleet in the Atlantic numbers 5 battleships, 5 cruisers, 2 transports, a hospital- ship, and a collier.
(Reuter.)
Russia has accepted the draft of the conven- tion which has been proposed by Great Britain.
(Reuter.)
The International Commission regarding the Hull incident will meet in Paris shortly. (H.)

An officially-inspired statement says that, before Admiral Rodjestvensky sailed, he receiv ed from secret agents a mass of information showing that Japanese torpedo-boats were in European waters, and that also a number of fishing boats had been purchased at Hamburg, Hull, Southampton, and Christiana by the Japanese. In view of these facts, the Admiralty asked Germany, Great Britain, and Denmark for a special safeguard as regards the track of the squadron. Admiral Rodjestvensky, on the night of the 21st October, received a wireless telegram, apparently from the transport Kamchatka, 30 miles in the rear, asking for the latitude and longitude of the remainder of the squadron. Admiral Rodjestvensky suspected a Japanese ruse to locate the Russians. Directly afterwards a searchlight was thrown on the Baltic fleet by the supposed Japanese. The Admiral then made out the forms of two torpedo-boats.
(Reuter.)

The Commission accepted by Russia is described by Articles 9 to 14 of the Hague treaty. It will be composed as telegraphed on the 3rd inst., and will meet in Paris as soon as possible-probably within a fortnight after the convention is signed. The Commission will fix the responsibility of both parties, who are pledged to supply all the necessary information. (Reuter.)
The Russian volunteer steamer Yaroslav, with coal and water, to-day passed the Bos- phorus, in order to join the Baltic fleet. (R.)

Admiral Sir C. Bridge and Mr. Aspinall, K.C., yesterday opened the Board of Trade enquiry. They are inspecting the damaged trawlers. A representative has gone to the Dogger Bank to examine the fishermen. (R.)
THE WAR.
FREQUENT NIGHT ATTACKS.
FALL OF FIRST SNOW.
MUKDEN, November 5.
The two armies are so close to each other
that manoeuvring is almost impossible. There are frequent night attacks on both sides.
It is believed that the Japanese are awaiting the result of the attack on Port Arthur- which took place on the 3rd inst.-before advancing against General Kuropatkin.
The Japanese have received large reinforcements.
The first snow fell to-day.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
PORT ARTHUR.
CAPTURE OF FORTS AND GUNS.
RUSSIAN SHIPS SUNK.

div.p: The Japanese captured several forts in the region north of Port Arthur on the 30th and 31st October.
(Havas.)

(Official). On the 30th, October, the Japa- nese occupied the crest of the counterscarp of several of the north forts, including that of Erlung-shan, and captured 5 guns. During the following days they bombarded the shipyard, sinking 5 steamers and causing a fire in the harbour.
(Reuter.)

div.head: SERIOUS AFFRAY AT INNSBRUCK. RENEWED RIOTING.
div.p: A serious affray occurred here on Thursday and Friday between Germans and Italians. The cause of the trouble was the opening of the Italian Faculty at the University. About 20 were killed and wounded. The University was wrecked. The incident is likely to embitter the relations between Italy and Austria.
The rioting was renewed to-day. The gen- darmes charged the crowd with fixed bayonets. The garrison has been reinforced.
(Reuter.)

div.head: GENERAL ANDRE.
div.p: Numerous notabilities have paid visits to
Gen. André.
(Havas.)

div.head: FRENCH ELECTION.
div.p: M. Augagneur, the Mayor, and a Socialist, has been elected a deputy.
(Havas.)

div.head: PUBLIC WORKS TENDERS.
div.p: The tender of Mr. Fucile for the construction of seven intakes for the branches of the Samana Canal, in the Facous district of the Sharkieh province, at the cost of L.E. 1,120, has been accepted.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.-
div.p: On the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd inst. 37 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 23 were British, 5 German, 2 French, 3 Austrian, 1 Italian, 1 Danish, and 2 Dutch. The total transit and passenger dues collected for the three days on 37 vessels amounted to 1,102,727.72 frs.

div.head: EGYPTIAN AGRICULTURISTS' SYNDICATE.-
div.p: The November issue of the Journal of this syn- dicata contains an article by Dr. C. Surri on the malady of the Albizzia Lebbek and a further instalment of Mr. A. Faget's discus- sion of agricultural legislation in Egypt, wherein the jurisprudence relating to Moukabala is dealt with in great detail.

div.head: TELEGRAPHS IN CYPRUS.-
div.p: An Order in Council is published in the latest London Gazette to hand making provision for the "installation and working of telegraphic (in- eluding wireless) apparatus in Cyprus, and for the control in certain events by the High Commissioner over the transmission of mes-
sages.

div.head: ENGLISH SOLDIER KILLED.
div.p: An accident, which terminated fatally, occurred at Mustapha Pasha station on the Ramleh Railway on Sa- turday evening. Private George Martin, of the 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, alighted from a tram in motion, which did not stoff at Mustapha Pasha. He appears to have alighted on some rails and tripped up, with the result that he fell against the tram. He sus- tained shocking injuries and a leg had to be amputated. He died at Ras-el-Tin Hospital yesterday. He was a very steady, respectable man, and his death is greatly regretted in the regiment.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: On the occasion of his return to the Capital and 1st of Ramadan, the Khedive will hold a reception at Abdeen Palace to-morrow evening commencing at 7.30 o'clock, H.H. the Khedivah will receive European ladies from 3.30 to 4.15 p.m. and the wives of the diplomatic agents at 4.20 p.m., at Koubbeh Piace.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Hon. Fred. G. Morgan, acting American Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General, is staying at Mena House.
Bishop Morley left Alexandria- to-day for Cairo by the noon train.
Colonel Harrington Bey is expected to pay a visit to Alexandria shortly.
The Messrs. Schmoll, from Berlin, have arriv ed at sunny "Al Hayat" from the Continental Hotel, Cairo, for a long stay.
Mr. and Mrs. Schmoll, Mrs. von Kaltembach
and son, Baron Benno von Schenk, Major von Arnim and family, and Miss Symons are shortly expected at "Al Hayat."

div.head: SUDAN IRRIGATION SERVICE
div.p: PARTICULARS OF PROJECT.

A Note of importance issued by the P. W. D yesterday refers to the Sudan. After stating that before any of the schemes mentioned in Sir William Garstin's Report for obtaining a perfect control of the waters of the Nile for the benefit of Egypt, and eventually intro ducing a system of irrigation into the Sudan, can be decided upon, a thorough survey with extensive records of the Nile levels is abso lutely necessary.

It has therefore been determined to detach certain functionaries from the Irrigation Service of the Egyptian Government who will be considered to be charged with a special mission of indefinite duration. Each of these functionaries will receive a special allowance during the whole of his residence in the Sudan. Besides these officials of the permanent staff, a number of provisional officials will be recruited to form the "higher provisional personnel," or, "provisional technical personnel." They will all be entitled to a special provision for travelling expenses, according to the provisions of the Financial Code, and it is of course understood that in the case of the permanent staff the length of their service in the Sudan will count as entitling them to pension in accordance with the provisions of the Code above-mentioned.

In view of the unhealthiness of a great part of the Sudan it is proposed to give officials of both categories every possible chance of visiting Europe once a year. They will therefore be entitled to 3 months' leave a year at full pay. The post to be occupied by the permanent functionaries and the allowances granted them are as follows:-
One Inspector General of Irrigation with Egyptian pay at the rate of L.E. 1,000 per annum and Sudan pay of L.E. 500.
One Assistant Inspector with L.E. 600, plus L.E. 200.
One Assistant Engineer with L.E. 240, plus L.E. 200.
One Accountant with L.E. 180, plus L.E.

As these functionaries are permanent, new posts are to be created, and they will be considered as on a special mission to the Sudan.If through ill-health or any other cause they have to be recalled to Egypt, they will cease to obtain the Sudan allowance and will only receive the effective pay of their former Egyptian post. They will be replaced in the Sudan service by other functionaries who volunteer for the vacant posts, so that the Egyptian service may
not suffer.

It will be eventually necessary to recruit a number of provisional agents. For the present they will only be recruited as the need for their services arises. This branch of the per- sonnel will consist of assistant engineers, clerks, surveyors, and levellers. Their pay will be proportionate to the importance of their work, clerks and assistant engineers being placed on the same footing with the perma- nent staff in the matter of leave and travelling expenses, Surveyors and levellers will be paid by the month, this pay including special allowances.

A sum of L.E. 24,000 figures in the proposed, Budget for 1905 as allotted to the study of irrigation in the Sudan, which includes cost of steamer hire, instruments, equipment, river work, etc. It is impossible to give the details of the expenditure proposed in the latter cases. This may depend on unknowndata, i.e., new and difficult conditions of climate and transport and the supply of labour.

Though the first object of the mission of the officials in question will be the study of various projects relating to the control of the Nile, they must be always ready to act as technical advisers to H.E. the Governor-General of the Sudan should he wish to consult them on the subject of the many questions concerning local irrigation, or about concessions of land in the Sudan territory.

The Minister of Public Works proposes to appoint Mr. C. Dupuis, Inspector of the 2nd Circle of Irrigation in Egypt, as Inspector- General of Irrigation in the Sudan. The fuuctionaries of the second class will be chosen by the Minister among those who agree to serve in the Sudan.
The Minister hopes that the Council of Ministers will approve the above proposals.

div.head: BARRAGE AT ESNEH.
div.p: We hear that the plans for the proposed Nile Barrage at Esneh are being drawn up at the Ministry of Public Works.

div.head: ITALIAN BANKING DEVELOPMENTS.
div.p: Mr. Pacelli, Chairman of the Board of the Banco di Roma, and two of the directors of that bank left Alexandria on Saturday on their return to Italy. It has been definitely decided to found a branch of the bank here, and a well-known local banking man is to be appointed to the post of manager of the branch. This Alexandria branch will have a capital of 10,000,000 frs., and it is expected to be open early next year.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Syrian Pris ce, from Manchester, lef Malta on Saturday and is due here on Wed.esday, with passengers and general cargo.
The Mesageries Maritimes S.S. Niger, which left Marseilles on the BA inst, passed the Straits of Messina last Saturday at 1 p.m. and is due here to morrow.
The Moss liner Maris railed hence yesterday morning for Liverpool with general cargo, including 6,746 bales cosion.
The S.S. Perim, of the Westcott and Laurance Line, left Malta last Saturday and is due here on Wednesday with general cargo from Newcastle and London, vis Valta.
The Cunard 88. Cypria will arrive here on Wednesday next, ready to load cargo for Liverpool and American porte.

div.head: GOLD IN EGYPT.
div.p: £5,000 BULLION BROUGHT INTO
ASSOUAN.
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).

Assonan, November 6. Mr. A. P. Mack, managing director of the Nile Valley Company, and Mr. John M. Beck- with, manager of the mine, arrived at Assouan yesterday from Um Garaiart, bringing in five thoasand pounds worth of bullion, which has been deposited with the Bank of Egypt for shipment to England.
Messrs. Mack and Beckwith left for Cairo to-day; the former is going home. Mr. Oxley left at the same time for England.

div.head: THE GREEK SQUADRON.
div.p: The Greek Squadron, consisting of trhee 1st- class armoured cruisers, the Psarà, flagship, the Hydra, and the Spetsas, under the command of Commodore D. Coundourioti, aide-de-camp to the King of Greece, arrived on Saturday morning from Algiers. After dropping anchor in front of Ras-el-Tin Palace, it saluted the Egyp tian flag with 21 guns, the band playing the Egyptian hymn at the same time. The steamer Bear, of the Bell's Asia Minor Line, having on board the band of the Greek Philharmonie So- ciety, together with the committee of reception, went out to meet the ships, and altogether a hundred small boats, including steam launches, collected round the advancing squadron, greeting it with enthusiastic cheers.

After the usual sanitary visit, etc., Mr. C. Sinopoulo, the Hellenic Vice-Consul, went on board to arrange with the Commodore the details of the reception. At 3 o'clock in the afternoon, M. N. Scotidis, the Hellenic Consul, accom- panied by his staff, in full uniform, paid an official visit to the flag-ship, and was received with due honours. At 4 o'clock, a special steam launch took on board the committee for the reception, viz., MS. Benachi, president of the Greek community, M. M. Sinadino, the vice- president, Messrs. B. Civitanidis, D. Theodo- rakis, S. Farngiscates, L. Limpritis, J. Cartalis, A. Benachi, E. Paraskeva, and S. Delta.

During the afternoon an iminiense crowd of visitors went on board to see the ships. The Commodore dined on Saturday night at the house of Mr. and Mrs. Michel Sinadino, and, appeared afterwards at the Zizinia Theatre, where a lot of the officers were also present.

All the shops and private houses and offices belonging to Greek subjects were profusely decorated with national flags for the occasion. Yesterday, after the usual service at the Greek Orthodox Church, "Evangelismos, "a spe- cial Te Deum service was sung at 10.30 a.m., the Patriarch Photios officiating, with all his clergy, amidst an immense concourse of people. At about 10 o'clock, Commodore Coundourioti, accompanied by the Consul, Mr. N. Scotidis, drove up in the private carriage of Mr. Bena- chi and was received with loud cheers and the strains of the Greek national hymn, played by the Greek Philharmonic Society, stationed in the square before the church. The Commo- dore was shown to his allotted place, amidst his staff and the other officers of the fleet, by the members of the committee for the reception. The Te Deum, sung by the full choir of the church, was extremely solemn and impressive, especially the Byzantine music, rendered by a tenor in solo, which attracted general attention. At the end of the Te Deum, the Patriarch addressed the congregation very eloquently. After welcoming the officers and men, he dwelt upon the historical and religious associations between Greece proper and Alex- andria. He explained to the congregation that every Greek coming to Alexandria was not coming to a strange land, but was coming to a place of which the origin was Greek, having been founded by Alexander the Great, and he impressed the congregation with the great and important role which Alexandria had played in the early days of Christianity, by pro- pagating that religion. He then lauded the patriotic sentiments of the Hellenic colony in Egypt, which he impressed upon his hearers as being very rich and powerful, and which in reality formed part of the strength of the mother country. He terminated by explaining that all the hopes of the realisation of national aspirations were centred on the navy. He ended by calling for cheers for his Majesty the King of Greece, which were rendered with the greatest enthusiasm and spirit.

The departure of the Commodore and staff was effected amidst tremendous enthusiasm and excitement, expressed by the large crowds of people massed outside the church, the num ber of people éstimated in and out being about 10,000 souls. A body of 300 sailors drawn from the three ships formed a guard of honour in church.

Amongst the congregation we remarked Mr. and Mrs. E. Benachi, Mr. and Mrs. M. Salvago, Mr. and Mrs. M. Sinadino, Mr. G. Zervoudachi, Mr. and Mrs. Theodorakis, Mr. and Mrs. Joanides, Mr. J. Cartalis, Mr. and Mrs. A. Benachi, Mr. and Mrs. S. Delta, Mr. A. Car- talis, Mr. J. Pesmatsoglou, director general of the Bank of Athens, Mr. and Mrs. Choremi, Mr. A. Kephala, Dr. and Mrs. Valasopoulos, Mr. and Mrs. Aslan, Mr. and Mrs. N. Tamvaco, all the members of the Hellenic Club, and many others.

The order in church, thanks to the excellent arrangements of the committee, was exem- plary. Great confusion, however, reigned out- side on the exit of the congregation, owing to the almost entire absence of the police, which was very much remarked and commented upon. After the service, the Commodore and his staff, and the other officers of the fleet, drove to the Patriarchate, where a reception was held, and subsequently went to the Gouver norat where they were presented to Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, the Governor of Alexandria, by the Consul General.
Mr. and Mrs. E. Benachi entertained the Commodore with his staff and other officers, at their residence last night, where all the leading members of the Greek community were invited to meet them,

div.head: POLYTECHNIC SCHOOL.
div.p: ENTRANCE ON A NEW ERA.
We give a resumé of a very important Note issued yesterday by the Ministry of Public Works bearing the signature of H.E. Fakhry Pasha.

The Note opens by observing that the atten- tion of the Ministry of Public Works has been called for some time past to the yearly diminu- tion in the number of candidates for the Poly- technic School at Ghizeh. There could be no doubt as to the causes of this diminution. Employment under the Ministry of Public Works was not looked upon as lucrative, and the majority of youths who had successfully passed through the Government secondary schools preferred to study Law or Medicine owing to the wider field and higher emolu- ments promised by these professions. Moreover, doctors in the employ of the Egyptian Govern- ment were allowed to occupy themselves as well with private practice, while engineers serving under the Ministry of Public Works were most strictly forbidden to engage in any but governmental work.

There were other and important reasons to account for the unpopularity of the service. The work was extremely difficult and its difficulties and extent showed a tendency to increase pari passu with the extension of irrigation. The life was often solitary, far from the large centres, and trying to a degree; promotion was slow and the number of prizes attainable very limited. The decrease in the number of pupils admitted to the Polytechnic began in 1899. The figures from 1897 onwards were as follows: 1897, 15; 1898, 20; 1899, 13; 1900, 9; 1901, 4; 1902, 3; 1903, 1. In 1904 7 pupils were attracted through the well-founded belief that the conditions of service would shortly be improved.

It has now been decided to make certain modifications in the numbers of the cadres and in the salaries paid, which will involve an in- crease of L.E.25,848 in the Budget of the Mi- nistry. On leaving the Polytechnic School suc- cessful pupils will at once receive L.E.12 instead of LE.8, which was by no means a high rate of pay if the high standard of education de- manded in the case of candidates for the Poly- technic School was taken into account. Engi- neers of all classes will have a rise of pay granted them-e.g., chief engineers of the 1st class will be entitled to a maximum of L.E.50 per month while their monthly pay has hitherto amounted only to L.E.30. To every one in possession of the facts respecting the work and duties of chief engineers this does not seem any too much.

It is also believed that the increase of sala- ries will improve the morale of the service, for, though it never was suggested that a majority of the personnel were corrupt, the Ministry regretfully acknowledges that certain accusa- tions of dishonesty proved in some cases to be only too well-founded. Poor pay is no excuse for dishonesty and corruption, but under certain circumstances it may be pleaded as an exte- nuating circumstance, and though it is not contended that an increase of pay will make an honest out of a corrupt employé, it is pro- bable that members of the service who have leanings to dishonesty will be kept in check by the knowledge of the greater importance of their positions from a financial point of view, while the honest employé will be far less subject to temptation.

This augmentation of pay will not extend to all members of the service. Certain of the agents of the Ministry have rendered them- selves subject to just suspicion of dishonesty and they are not intended to benefit from the new regulations. Nor will length of service in a certain class entitle any official to a rise of salary. The Ministry shall alone have the right to decide which of its present employés deserve to enjoy higher pay, while the recruits will start directly under the new scale.

The actual increase of the numbers of the cadres is due to the creation of a new Circle, with Zifta as its headquarters, and the division of the Minieh province into two sections, each under a chief engineer.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD
div.p: ALEXANDRIA
5c. PER DAY, WINE INCLUDED

div.head: UNLUCKY CONDENSERS.
div.p: The condensers for Suakin seem to be very unlucky. The erecting engineer, Mr. Craw- ford, who was sent out by the firm to put up the condenser wrecked by the Afghanistan, had to be sent home again as unfit for Suakin. The firm then sent out another erecting en gineer, Mr., Simpson, to put up the condenser just arrived by the Mooristan, but this gentle- man has fallen ill and been pronounced medically unfit for Suakin also. He therefore returns home by the S.S. Mehallah today. It is to be hoped that the next engineer will be able to stand the climate as the condenser is badly needed here.

div.head: DISASTROUS STORM.
div.p: On the evening of the 16th inst., a very heavy rainstorm passed over Graham's Point and Suakin, which lasted for 1 hours. The storm, which was accompanied by hail, thunder, and lightning, was of great severity. Such a storm has not been experienced here for many years. Several houses collapsed at Suakin and some wooden roofs were blown away for a great distance. At Graham's Point all the tents were uprooted and blown away, causing a panic among those living in them. A new iron running shed, recently put up and not quite completed, was torn up and thrown down, most of the ironillare and angle irons being damaged. The railway banks, about 5 feet high, were washed away and levelled to the ground outside Suakin town. Next morning, Col. Macauley Bey, Director of Railways, accompanied by Bimbashi Lord, acting chief engineer, took a special train from Graham's Point and inspected the whole of the new line as far as Railhead. He immediately ordered staff officer Aly Effendy Shawky, with a few hundred Arabs and soldiers, to repair the damage done. The line is in working order again after a few days' hard work.

div.head: ARRIVALS AT SUAKIN.
div.p: Two Khedivial Mail steamers arrived on the 19th, the Missir and the Gharbiek, both from Suez. The Gharbieh came direct as a "special" with consignments for the Sudan Government, Suakin, while the Missir came via Jeddah and left yesterday for Aden. The Gharbieh will return to Suez in a few days.

The passengers who arrived here by the Missir are Mr. Luard, agent for the Bank of Egypt, Suakin branch, and Mr. Smart, from England, who has been appointed Chief Store- keeper, Sudan Government Railways, Suakin, in place of Mr. Lessona (at present on leave in Europe), who is transferred to the Engineering Department. It is with regret that I have to mention the loss sustained by Mr. Lessona in the death of his wife in Italy, which was the cause of his going on leave for 3 months.
Several workmen also arrived here from Suez by the Gharbieh for the Sudan Government Railways.

div.head: H.M.S. "HERMIONE" AT SUEZ.
div.p: Suez, Sunday-The British cruiser Hermione came out of the Canal at 10 a.m. She will be provisionally stationed at Suez in order to follow the movements of the Baltic squadron, which is due to pass through the Canal in a few days.
Port Said, Sunday.-H.M.S. Furious is ex- pected to arrive at Port Said to-morrow from Malta.
H.M.S. Hermione will remain at Suez for some days.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: OFFER OF PURCHASE OF SITE.
The plot of land on which stands the Khe-
divial Opera House in Cairo is the subject of au offer of purchase at £40 a metre. The Government are considering the offer.

div.head: A MIXED COURT SCANDAL
div.p: A Council of Discipline of the MIX Courts of Alexandria, under the presidency of Judge Ernest Eeman, has ordered Ahmed Bakri, an official of the Mixed Courts, to be dismissed for having made scratches upon the public registers. The dossier of the affair will shortly be communicated to the Native Parquet with a view to criminally prosecuting this man.

div.head: SANITARY DEPARTMENT.
div.p: On the proposition of the Director General of the Department, the Minister of the Interior has been pleased to approve of the permanent appointment of Dr. Charles Forrester as assistant inspector of the 1st class at L.E. 30 per month, being the minimum pay of the class, dating from November 3.
Miss Edith H. Coxon, Matron of the Kasr- el-Ainy Hospital, having tendered her resignation, her name is struck off the strength of the Department.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL,
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramieh. First Class Hotel. Newly built. Ben breeses. alr. Near tramway station, the promenade, Mustapha Pasha Barraoke, Garden, Lawn Tennis Good enisins, Moderate charges. div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit within certain necessary limita-free discussion.

div.head: HYDROPHOBIA IN CAIRO.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,-There have been numerous cases of late in Cairo where persons have been bitten by mad dogs. In one case I know of many members of a Jewish family were attacked by a pet dog, who had been bitten by a parish is the streets and had become mad. There are far too many stray pariahs in Cairo, and the numbers of these dogs are in no way visibly decreased, despite the official statistics you published, in Friday's issue. The fact is that the whole system of poisoning dogs in Cairo is cruel and inefficacious. The inexperienced members of the canine community, when they chance to have swallowed a toothsome morsel baited by their enemies, writhe for hours in agony. Their shrieks are appalling during all the hours of the night. Yet they sometimes recover. The older hands know far too well the look and smell of their official quietus, and refuse to touch it at any price. If all the pariahs and stray dogs in Cairo were given poison as often as the announcements in your columns' would lead us to believe, there would not be a single dog left in all Cairo. But I am afraid both the meat and the poison pass into channels other than that for which they are intended. The meat may possibly be eaten by the policeman himself or distributed amongst his friends, while the poison can be disposed of for a consideration at the nearest bakkal, of which we have legions. Hinc illa lacrima.
1 am, etc.,

div.head: BRITISH TRADE IN EGYPT.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Sir,-I have not the pleasure of the acquaint- ance of your Cairo correspondent who writes to you under the pseudonym of "Rags," but I most cordially congratulate that gentleman on giving your readers such a forcible exposition of his experience, which I can fully endorse. If the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt is of any practical utility, it could not render a better service to Anglo-Egyptian trade than in bringing the injustice from which traders at home suffer to the notice of those who guide the destinies of British trade in Egypt, as well as te that small, but not unimportant, section of the official community who compile elaborate consular reports, filled with statistical items, which no business man has the leisure to solve. The sooner British manufacturers bestir themselves and try to keep the representation of their firms in British hands in Egypt, the better it will be for all parties.
1 am, etc.,

div.head: CLUB CLUBBING EXTRAORDINARY,
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,- Whatever do the Recreation people want! I have always understood that their club was formed as their businesses did not allow of their enjoying the advantages of a re- gular club, and that they were so tied down to desks, counters, and benches, that Ghezireh, where the Sporting Clubgrounds are, was too far away for them, except at night time. What would the Recreation people do with the Sporting Club grounds if they got them? Shut families out for six days a week, as they did at their own club? Let the Recreation people put their own house in order before attempting to meddle with that of others."
Cairo, November 6.
I am, etc.,

div.head: A DENIAL
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Dear Sir,- With reference to the letter which appeared in your Saturday's issue, per- mit me, as a member of the B.R.C. committee, to point out that the remarks made by Mr. Knight Foley, re Ghezireh grounds, have no official authorization or inspiration from the committee.
Cairo, November 6.
Yours truly,

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Nous avons débuté la sem ina dernière avec un marché très ferme et une forte t n- dance à la hausse; mais, soit à cause d'évé- nements politiques imprévus ou d'une im- portante liquidation de fin du mois, les cours ont fléchi vers la fin sur toute la ligne. Le marché à terme de notre place & pris, en effet, de telles proportions qu'il rend très mouvementée chaque échéane de quinzaine ou de fin du mois. Si l'on sjouts à cela que les spéculateurs s'étaient surchargés et que les prix avaient été pous- sés trop vite, on comprendra qu'une réac- tion était inévitable. La crise monétaire n'y est cependant pour rien. L'insignifiance jusqu'à ce jour des arrivages de coton de l'in- térieur laisse encore à chacun la libre dispo- sition de ses capitaux. Cette crise n'en est pas moias attendue d'un moment à l'autre et c'est dans cette prévision que les banques font des difficultés pour les avances sur titres. Une bonne note pour notre place c'est la faveur de plus en plus marquée dont jouissent les valeurs égyptiennes su les marchés étrangers. Délaissés, il y a quelque temps, elles prennent décidément un pied de plus en plus ferme à Paris et surtout à Londres.
La Banque Nationale débute très ferme à 23 1/4, fléchit quelques jours après à 22 18/16, et remonte à 23 5/16 pour clô- turer vendeure à 22 11/16.
Il y a eu sur l'Agricole un mouvement considérable. Ap.ès avoir débaté à 10 7/8 et atteint à un moment donné 11 1/8, le prix tombe en elô:ure à 10 11/16.

Par suite du retard des arrivages da coton les recettes marchandises de la Delts Light ont été quelque peu inférieures à celle de la semaine correspondante de 1903, mais c'est là une baisse qui sera bientô plus que compensée et le bilan s'annonce, parait-il, excellent. Aussi la valear a--elle débuté ferme à 15 3/8 et après un fléchis- sement momentané à 15 1/4 elle a aussitô: repris à 15 S.S. Le prix de 15 1/2 a même été pratiqué. Beaucoup d'affaires.
La Deferred Delta est plus faible. Elle débute à 18 3/4 pour clôturer offerte à 17-3/4.
Rien de saillant pour les Tramways d'A- lexandrie. La Privilégiée fluctue de 142 1/2 à 144 et la Dividende de 864 à 374.
La Ramleh Railway r ste à peu près sans changement mais très ferme durant toute la semaine.

Lea Markets et surtout la Salt & Soda ont donné lieu à d'importantes transactions. Cette dernière semble surtout en faveur auprès du public. Le coure & atteint ven- dredi 28,prix de côture; quant aux Mar- kets, ils sont restés stationnaires à 24 durant toute la semaine.
Très fermes les Eaux du Caire ont atteint vendredi 972 1/2 et en clôture 980. Les Eaux d'Alexandrie ont un monent fait fureur, mais ont ensuite réactionné à 16 pour reprendre en clôture à 16 5/6.
La Daira reste calme et sons change-
ment.

Aujourd'hui le marché reprend sar toute la ligne et la plupart des valeurs sont en hausse. On a fait d: 6 à 7,000 Salt & Sola à un prix variant de 28 à 81, cours de clôture. Parmi les autres changements les plus notables, signalons la hausse de la Nationale à 22 7/8, du Crédit Foncier à 296, de l'Agricole à 10 13/16, de la Nungovich à 9.1/16, de la R.mlub Railway à 8 9/16 etc

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: L'ABBE CONSTANTIN CYRANO DE BERGERAC LE CEUR A SES RAISONS Pour se rendre compte avec que act M. Coquelin sait se grimer il suffit de le voir jouer après Tartufe l'Abbé Constantin. L'aspect odi ux et hypocrite du faux dévot fait si complétement place en lui à celui du curé de campagne, tout empreiat de bonté et de naïv té, que sa seule apparition sur la scène est déj un triomphe. L'exécution A été superb sous tous les rapports; les ro'es secondaires eux-mêmes ont été inter- puè és, d'une façon vraiment magistrale; le vireur, le lieutenant, Mme Scott et sa soeur et jurqu'à Pauline, tous ont été parfaits.

Dans Cyrano de Bergerac M. Coquelin est, on p ut le dire,inimitable. Ce rôle,qu'il erés en 1897 à la Porte Saint Martin dont il était à l'époque administrateur, fut on plus grand succès. Il l'est encore au- jourd'hui. La salle da Zizinia a retenti hier soir d'applaudissements enthou- siastes darant toute la représentation, mais où l'admiration a presque touché au félire c'est dans la déclaration d'amour au 3me acte et dans la scène finale de la mort de Cyrano. M. Coquelin a du reste des sides précieux; Mme Devoyd a été admi- rable dans le rôle de Roxane, M. Rozenberg lans celui de Gaich-s, M. Gramont dans celui de Lebret, M. Dauchy dans celui de Christian de Neuvillette et M. Chabert dans celui de Raguenesu.

La soirés avait commencé par la repré- sentation de la charmante comélie de MM. de Flers et A de Caillavet, Le Cur a ses raisons. Nous n'avons que des éloges à adresser aux artistes qui y ont pris part, Mine Devoyod a été excellente dans le rôle de Françoise Vernières, Mme Merle dans celui de la femme de chambre, M. Dauchy dans le rôle de Jaqs Artenay et M. Gramont dans celui de Lucien de Jullianges.
Ce soir on donne Le Député de Bombi- gnac, comédie en 3 actes de M. Alexandre Bis on et La Joie fait peur, comélie en I acte de Mine Emile de Girardia

Les provinces et administrations dont les revenus sont affectés au service de la Dette Unifiée ont versé ja qu'au 31 oc- tobre les sommes suivantes: la province de Gharbieh L E. 189.348,324, celle de Menoufieb L.E. 218.415,609, celle de Béhé- ra L.E. 114:015,055 et celle de Siout L.E. 306.952,628, les Doannes ont rapporté L.E. 727.238,370, les droits sur les tabacs d'importation L.E 1728.440 et les droits sur les sucres raffinés L.E. 6.000. Ces di- verses sommes réunies au reliquat du 30 Avril, L.E. 937 149,553, forment un total de LE 3 227 559,539.

En déduisant de ce total la demi-annuité de l'échéance du 1er septembre, soit L.E. 158.562,500 et la somme nécessaire au paiement du coupon de la Dette Unifiée du ler novembre, soit L.E. 1.091.453,220, on obtient un reliquat de L.E. 1.982.548,819.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE ASSOCIATION.
div.p: COTTON SECTION

Résumé of answers received in October 1904. The temperature during the month of October was warm and favourable to the cotton plants, with the exception of four or five days of light rain and cool weather.
On the other hand, the fogs which occurred almost daily have, in addition to those da ing September, pedtralized the effects of the heat

The cotton plants have suffered and complaints are rather numerous. The Behera Province espe civily has been adversely affected, whereas several other provinces have boea affeeted to a far smaller ex ent and the Esstern ones are considered scarcely to have suffered at all.
The first picking is finishel and the second is well advanced in many districtes, their resuls will be less than was hoped for ia September.
As regards the top erop waish suffered most of all it will be much less than last year's.
The yield in gianing coatings to be very irre- gular and averages from two to th-e per cent. below last year's.
In Upper-Egypt the orop is very good; the one in the Fayoum has been less favoared.

O the whole the ioform tions are less favourable than in Septembr,sad taking into due coarideration the increase of acresgs, especially in Upper-Egypt, we are led to estimate the total arop at about 61 mill.on cantars.
We consider the quality to be below last year's in class.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: "Rule Britannia." Were it not for the British Fleet, which has the happy knack of being there or thereabouts when wanted, Russia would not have climbed down so gracefully before the indignation of outraged Great Britain. She is indeed still the Mistress of the Sea, and shall be, for the crisis brought home to the most unthinking of us how much we owe to our matchless Navy.

With the view of reducing expenditure, and at the same time promoting the efficiency of the personnel, the Lords of the Admiralty have come to the conclusion that in the interest of the Service it is eminently desirable that the "weeding out" of small or more or less obsolete craft should be at once commenced. The upkeep of these vessels represents in the aggregate a large sum annually, without, it is held, any real benefit being derived therefrom, and what is even of greater importance, the officers and men by whom they are manned are without opportunities for gunnery and torpedo practice. The ini- tiative in the new departure has been taken, orders having been issued that the Pearl, third-class cruiser, Captain E. P. Ashe, is to be withdrawn from the Cape of Good Hope station without a relief being sent to take her place: The Vestal, Rinaldo, and Espiegle, sloops, serving on the China station, are to return to England to be paid off and reliefs will not be despatched to take their place. The Tweed, an old gunboat assigned to the China station for coast defence, will be paid off into the Reserve at Hong Kong and her crew sent home.

A very smart officer of the Royal Engineers, Brevet-Major E. V. Turner, presently employed with the Telegraph Battalion, London, has been selected for service with the Egyptian Army. He joined the sappers in July, 1892, was promoted to his present rank in the July of last year, and was attached to the West African Frontier Force for some time and earned the medal with clasp in the Hinterland operations of 1898. He was in Ladysmith throughout the siege of that garrison and the campaign of 1901 (medal with clasps, mentioned in dispatches). He got his brevet majority for good service in Lagos last year.

div.head: "A POTENTIAL SUCCESSOR TO LORD CROMER."
div.p: A London contemporary remarks:-In Lord Edward Herbert Cecil, who has just gone back to his post as Director of Intelligence in the Sudan, there is a potential successor to Lord Cromer. During his three and a half years of Egyptian service he has displayed in a marked degree the qualities of a good administrator. He is thirty-seven, a brilliant soldier, and a man of business as well as of affairs. The besieged in Mafeking owe him a large debt. They had pretty bad times there long before the siege was over, but had it not been for Lord Edward Cecil they would have starved long before relief came. He took upon himself the res- ponsibility of providing the town with just four times the quantity of food the military authorities found necessary, and when the contractors hesitated to execute a seven thousand pound order on the young major's sole responsibility, Lord Edward promptly got Baden-Powell to back the bill. But Mafeking was only one incident in his career. He has served in Egypt several times, accompanied the famous special mission to King Menelik of Abyssinia, gained two medals for his services with the Dongola Expedition, earned more fame at Atbara, and added to it at Omdurman the D.S.O. and two clasps. The mission to Menelik, by the way, nearly put an end to Lord Edward's career. While the party was on its way one of the camels fell down a deep ravine, and Lord Edward and Captain Swayne clambered down a rope of puggarees with the idea of rescuing the animal. They could not reach the camel, however, and one of the Abyssinians went down. A moment later two shots rang out one of them came pretty near to hitting Sir Rennell Rodd-and the native came up hand over hand in double- quick time. He had found two lions devouring the camel! Lord Edward, who is, of course, a younger brother of the Marquess of Salis- bury, married in 1894 Miss Violet Maxse, daughter of the late Admird Maxse and sister to the editor of the National Review. As a girl, Lady Edward Cecil sat for Millais' "Puss in Boots," and during the Boer war she did splendid work among the sick and wounded.

div.head: INAUGURAL RACES.
div.p: The Fayoum races came off yesterday on the race-course at Azeb. There was an excellent attendance and some good racing was witness- ed. Among those present I noticed Mouheb Bey, the Moudir, the Inspector of the Agri- cultural Bank of Egypt, Mr. Dray, who is attached to the Sanitary Administration here, and a large crowd of officials and notables. The result of the racing was as follows:---
First Race:--
1st prize: H. Marsoul's Fethy Bey. 2nd prize: H. Subiha's Kolieb Rimah Tribe.
Second Race:-
Ist prize: H. Mohrouss's Tantawee. 2nd prize: H. Obiiou's Honbouli.
Third Race, confined to Syrian horses. 1st prize: H. Mekleba's Hidar.

2nd prize: H. Siad's Mr. Iskandar Saab. The racing was of a high order and the events were quite on a par with any that can be seen at the Khedivial Sporting Club or the Alexandria Sporting Club. The interest dis- played by all was enormous, and this inaugura- tion of the Fayoum Sporting Club must be considered a success from every point of view. The races will take place on the first Friday of every month.

div.head: CRIMINALA STATISTICS.
div.p: From January 1st to November 1st the following cases have been disposed of by the Fayoum Tribunal: 135 crimes, 4,000 délits, 3,344 misdemeanours, 3,289 civil cases. These statistics show how greatly our local court is undermanned with only two judges. The increase in disputes among the people either shows that they are not progressing from the point of view of law and order, or else that the omdehs are becoming much more strict in reporting cases to the tribunals. I understand that the Ministry of Justice intends establishing a district court in the Fayoum as a relief to the present tribunal.

div.head: AN ANGLO-EGYPTIAN COMPANY.
div.p: The following is from the London Financier

"The Anglo-Egyptian Automatic Trading Company, Limited," is a curious name: The moment you see it you begin to ask yourself what upon earth "automatic trading" is. We are told "The objects of the company were to manufacture, buy, sell, and use automatic machines for the sale of goods." This company appears to have been indirectly assoociated with automatic companies which had previous- ly been promoted by Mr. Stuart Dixon Ross, Mr. Geo. Ross, and Mr. John Tweedy Scott, who "have avoided attendance upon the Offi- cial Receiver."

Some of the companies previously promoted by the Rosses and Tweedy Scott were Auto- matics, Limited, the Automatic Supply Com- pany, Limited, the Automatic Telegram and Letter Delivery Company, Limited, and the Automatic General Stores, Limited. Most of these names might mean anything, but we think the words "Automatic Telegram and Letter Delivery Company" can have only one meaning, and we are quite at a loss to con- ceive how the company manipulated the automatic delivery of letters and tele- grams. With Automatics, Limited, and the Automatic Supply Company, Limited, we have nothing to do, but the Automatic Telegram and Letter Delivery Company and the Auto- matic General Stores were formed into a group with the Anglo-Egyptian Automatic Trading Company, the company whose affairs we are discussing, and a kind of lord paramount com- pany called the British and Colonial Automatic Trading Company, Limited, was formed for taking over this little group of companies.

How far this intention was carried out does not appear, but it seems that the price payable to the Anglo-Egyptian Automatic Trading Company included 25,500 shares in the British and Colonial Company, and that, in addition to having to issue these 25,500 shares, the British and Colonial Company was in the debt of the Anglo-Egyptian Company to the extent of £12,000.

A company with all this to its credit ought surely to keep out of liquidation. But no. For some reason or other somebody induced one of H.M. Judges to makea winding-up order. "The statement of affairs shows liabilities £7,462, against assets valued at £30,500, and a sur- plus of £22,737 in the account with the share- holders; but the 'Official Receiver remarks that the statement is imperfect, and cannot be accepted as representing the true position of the company." Which, we may remark, con- sists of the shares held by the company in the British and Colonial Company, and the £12,000 due from the same company.

div.head: IRRIGATION AND CULTIVATION.
div.p: Very great satisfaction is expressed by the farmers in this province, from the fellah with, but a span of land to the big agriculturist with thousands of feddans, at the unexpected- ly successful results from irrigation this year. The Nile has been distinctly poor and the farming interest regarded the outlook with dismay. This year's flood in every respect resembled that of 1902, when 100,000 feddans of agricultural land were left sharaki. Mr. Webb in his report estimated that the sharaki lands in the Keneh Moudirieh would amount to 90,000 feddans. Fortunately, our local authorities were equal to the emergency. Sidky Bey, Inspector of our Circle, adopted a policy of the extremest economy and not a drop of water was allowed to run waste. The result is that we have 70,000 feddans of land irrigated, and only 20,000 feddans are left sharaki owing to their position on high levels, which the water cannot reach. The Moudir and Sub-Moudir are also to be congratulated on this happy result. They supplied the Irrigation officials with many hundreds of workmen in the villages in order to construct hawashats to save the water.

I regret to announce the death of the chief of the noblesse of Keneh, the "Nageeb," or patron, of the mosque of Sidi Abd el-Rahim. He was very widely respected by all classes of the community, both Moslem and Copt, and his funeral was very largely attended.
FATAL AFFRAY AT MOULED. Another Keneh correspondent writes to us as follows:-

Very grave rumours come to me anent the final day of the Keneh mouled. It appears a young fellah was strolling about in the com- pany of a fascinating damsel. There was a slight disagreement, what about, I cannot say, but it resulted in the damsel being. struck by the fellah with a bottle. The wound was not serious, but the minions of the law took sides with the fair one, and set upon the auiorous young man. He in turn got a kourbash and used it to some purpose, driving off his assailants for the time. They, however, came at him with a rush, and treated him so badly with nabouts and their feet, that he was taken to the caracol in a very damaged condition, so much so that the next day he died from his ill-treatment. The unfortunate young man's brother, who knew all about the occurrence, on learning that two official (1) medical men had given a certificate of death from natural causes, forbade the police to bury the body. He immediately took steps to obtain the ser- vices of an English doctor, who has testified that the man met his death by being kicked and otherwise ill-treated.

If the facts are as rumoured the whole of those implicated should receive the heaviest penalty the law can possibly give them. The medical men, who should be above suspicion, ought to be severely dealt with for having signed false declarations. There would also appear to be collusion on the part of the police.

div.head: ALWAYS AILING."
div.p: BUT NOT SICK ENOUGH TO KEEP
TO BED.
What a lot of people there are "always ailing," but not sick enough to keep to bed. How do you know them?
By their pale, sallow faces, dull eyes and hopeless appearance, thin in face and body, and always alarmed at their condition.

They will tell you their back aches, that their head and limbs ache; that they have no energy, are rheumatic, nervous, and irritable; can't sleep, can't eat; every little cold affects their back-they cough a little, and their heart acts strangely. They are generally miserable. Such people have kidney trouble, and don't
know it.

Their illness is caused by weak kidney action. The kidneys are clogged, and are keeping back in the body the uric acid and the fluid waste which cause urinary disorders, bladder troubles, Bright's disease and dropsy. Despondent as they are, it is difficult to convince them, and to get them to stop thinking about their ills.

But a cure is sure and certain. Doan's backache kidney pills will make them hearty and well, by helping the kidneys to drive out the disease-causing impurities from the body. This medicine is especially for kidney and urinary troubles, and can be relied upon as safe and certain. It does not open the bowels. For 72 years Doan's backache kidney pills have been in use, and they are the first medicine in the world for kidney and bladder troubles. They are for sale by all chemists

div.head: OUR POET'S CORNER.
div.p: THE BALTIC FLEET.
The Baltic Fleet is sailing upon the open sea: The crew are full of pluck and grit, and sing quite
joyfully:
No doubt they're looking for a job, which means
they want to fight;
They've actually been sniffing round the little Isle
of Wight.
The other night when all was dark, their searchlights
at full glow,
They came scroer some fishing smacks, and then
they cried, "What ho !
"This surely is the enemy; we'll knock them into
pap 1"
They thought each penny herring was a plucky little
Jap.
For nearly half an hour they plied their guns on
each small barque,
And twisted maste, like little trees blown down
inside a park.
And slaughtered honest fisher folk upon the open
And then they boldly sailed away, so gay and
pluckily !
But wait a while, the hour is nigh when every Jolly
Jack
Will he sailing o'er the ocean upon the Bassian's
track,
And if they like to chances fight, quite merrily we'll
sing,
Good luck to all the boys in blue, God save our
Gracious King.
J. DRAKE.

DE PARIS
n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles

en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par P'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recom- mencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
